title: 112_s3462
content: The Act is titled the "Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act" and it amends the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 to include anti-retaliation protection for whistleblowers. The "Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act" amends the Antitrust Criminal Penalty Enhancement and Reform Act of 2004 to provide whistleblower protections against retaliation for reporting violations of antitrust laws. The "Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act" provides whistleblower protections for reporting violations of antitrust laws, including assisting in investigations or proceedings related to such violations. The "Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act" offers whistleblower protections for reporting antitrust law violations or other criminal acts related to antitrust investigations. The Act does not protect whistleblowers who initiate or plan antitrust violations or other criminal activities. The "Criminal Antitrust Anti-Retaliation Act" provides whistleblower protections for reporting antitrust violations or other criminal acts. The term 'whistleblower' includes employees, contractors, subcontractors, or agents. The Act does not protect whistleblowers who plan or initiate obstruction of antitrust investigations. Whistleblowers protected from discrimination can seek relief by filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor or bringing an action in court if no decision is made within 180 days. Whistleblowers protected from discrimination can seek relief by filing a complaint with the Secretary of Labor under specific procedures outlined in the law. Whistleblowers can file a complaint with the Secretary of Labor within 180 days of the violation. If the order is not complied with, civil actions can be taken to enforce it in the district court. Whistleblowers who prevail in such actions are entitled to all necessary relief, including compensatory damages. Compensatory damages for whistleblowers under this section include reinstatement with the same seniority status, back pay with interest, and compensation for special damages such as litigation costs and attorney's fees. Whistleblowers retain all rights, privileges, and remedies under Federal or State law.
